For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.summary: The Property parameter contains the names of properties to be retrieved. If this parameter is given, the cmdlet returns a PSCustomObject containing only the requested properties. Wild-card patterns may be provided.

remarks.para: Any named properties that are not recognized are ignored. If no recognized properties are provided the cmdlet returns an empty PSCustomObject.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Conversion.TryParseHex(System.String,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Attempt to convert a string representation of a base-16 value into an integer.
member.param: A string containing the text to be parsed.
An integer into which the parsed value is stored. If the string cannot be converted, this parameter is set to 0.
member.returns: Returns true if the conversion was successful, false otherwise.
member.remarks: The hexString parameter must contain a hexadecimal value, with no base-indication prefix. For example, the string "0409" will be parsed into the base-10 integer value 1033, while the string "0x0409" will fail to parse due to the "0x" base-indication prefix.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Conversion.GetLocaleName(System.String)
member.summary: Attempt to create a object from a locale string as retrieved from WMI.
member.param: A string containing WMI's notion (usually) of a locale.
member.returns: A CultureInfo object if successful, null otherwise.
member.remarks: This method first tries to convert the string to a hex value and get the CultureInfo object from that value. Failing that it attempts to retrieve the CultureInfo object using the locale string as passed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Processor.NumberOfLogicalProcessors
member.summary: Number of logical processors for the current instance of the processor.
member.remarks: For processors capable of hyperthreading, this value includes only the processors which have hyperthreading enabled

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Processor.ProcessorID
member.summary: Processor information that describes the processor features.
member.remarks: For an x86 class CPU, the field format depends on the processor support of the CPUID instruction. If the instruction is supported, the property contains 2 (two) DWORD formatted values. The first is an offset of 08h-0Bh, which is the EAX value that a CPUID instruction returns with input EAX set to 1. The second is an offset of 0Ch-0Fh, which is the EDX value that the instruction returns. Only the first two bytes of the property are significant and contain the contents of the DX register at CPU reset—all others are set to 0 (zero), and the contents are in DWORD format

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Processor.SocketDesignation

If a computer system has two physical processors each containing two logical processors, then the value of CsNumberOfProcessors is 2 and CsNumberOfLogicalProcessors is 4. The processors may be multicore or they may be hyperthreading processors

member.summary: Type of the computer in use, such as laptop, desktop, or tablet.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsLocaleID
member.summary: Language identifier used by the operating system.
member.remarks: A language identifier is a standard international numeric abbreviation for a country/region. Each language has a unique language identifier (LANGID), a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsLocale
member.summary: The culture name, such as "en-US", derived from the property.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsLocalDateTime
member.summary: Operating system version of the local date and time-of-day.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsLastBootUpTime
member.summary: Date and time the operating system was last restarted.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsUptime
member.summary: The interval between the time the operating system was last restarted and the current time.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsBuildType
member.summary: Type of build used for the operating system.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsCodeSet
member.summary: Code page value the operating system uses.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDataExecutionPreventionAvailable
member.summary: If true, then the data execution prevention hardware feature is available.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDataExecutionPrevention32BitApplications
member.summary: When the data execution prevention hardware feature is available, this property indicates that the feature is set to work for 32-bit applications if true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDataExecutionPreventionDrivers
member.summary: When the data execution prevention hardware feature is available, this property indicates that the feature is set to work for drivers if true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy
member.summary: Indicates which Data Execution Prevention (DEP) setting is applied. The DEP setting specifies the extent to which DEP applies to 32-bit applications on the system. DEP is always applied to the Windows kernel.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDebug
member.summary: If true, the operating system is a checked (debug) build.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsDistributed
member.summary: If True, the operating system is distributed across several computer system nodes. If so, these nodes should be grouped as a cluster.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsEncryptionLevel
member.summary: Encryption level for secure transactions: 40-bit, 128-bit, or n-bit.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsForegroundApplicationBoost
member.summary: Increased priority given to the foreground application.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsTotalVisibleMemorySize
member.summary: Total amount, in kilobytes, of physical memory available to the operating system.
member.remarks: This value does not necessarily indicate the true amount of physical memory, but what is reported to the operating system as available to it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsFreePhysicalMemory
member.summary: Number, in kilobytes, of physical memory currently unused and available.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsTotalVirtualMemorySize
member.summary: Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsFreeVirtualMemory
member.summary: Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsInUseVirtualMemory
member.summary: Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently in use.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsTotalSwapSpaceSize
member.summary: Total swap space in kilobytes.
member.remarks: This value may be NULL (unspecified) if the swap space is not distinguished from page files. However, some operating systems distinguish these concepts. For example, in UNIX, whole processes can be swapped out when the free page list falls and remains below a specified amount

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsSizeStoredInPagingFiles
member.summary: Total number of kilobytes that can be stored in the operating system paging files—0 (zero) indicates that there are no paging files. Be aware that this number does not represent the actual physical size of the paging file on disk.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsFreeSpaceInPagingFiles
member.summary: Number, in kilobytes, that can be mapped into the operating system paging files without causing any other pages to be swapped out.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsPagingFiles
member.summary: Array of fiel paths to the operating system's paging files.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.OsHardwareAbstractionLayer
member.summary: Version of the operating system's Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL)

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy
member.summary: Data Execution Prevention (DEP) settings.

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.AlwaysOff
member.summary: DEP is turned off for all 32-bit applications on the computer with no exceptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.AlwaysOn
member.summary: DEP is enabled for all 32-bit applications on the computer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.OptIn
member.summary: DEP is enabled for a limited number of binaries, the kernel, and all Windows-based services. However, it is off by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator must explicitly choose either the Always On or the Opt Out setting before DEP can be applied to 32-bit applications.

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.OptOut
member.summary: DEP is enabled by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator can explicitly remove support for a 32-bit application by adding the application to an exceptions list.

member.summary: Stops the processing of the provider by using the CmdletProviderContext to tunnel the stop message to the provider instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Filter
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter property.
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Filter parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Include
member.summary: Gets or sets the include property.
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Include parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Exclude
member.summary: Gets or sets the exclude property.
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Exclude parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Force
member.summary: Gets or sets the force property.
member.remarks:
Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.
This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Force parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.summary: The following is the definition of the input parameter "StartupType". "Set-Service -StartType" sets ServiceController.InputObject.StartType. Changes the starting mode of the service. member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetServiceCommand.Status
member.summary: The following is the definition of the input parameter "Status". This specifies what state the service should be in (e.g. Running, Stopped, Paused). If it is already in that state, do nothing. If it is not, do the appropriate action to bring about the desired result (start/stop/suspend the service) and issue an error if this cannot be achieved. Status can be Paused , Running and Stopped.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to do ping test. Default is true.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to force use of IPv4 protocol.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to force use of IPv6 protocol.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to do reverse DNS lookup to get names for IP addresses.

member.summary: Gets the source from which to run the selected test. The default is localhost. Remoting is not yet implemented internally in the cmdlet.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.MaxHops
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of times the Ping data packets can be forwarded by routers. As gateways and routers transmit packets through a network, they decrement the Time-to-Live (TTL) value found in the packet header. The default (from Windows) is 128 hops.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.Count
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of ping attempts. The default (from Windows) is 4 times.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay between ping attempts. The default (from Windows) is 1 second.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.BufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the buffer size to send with the ping packet. The default (from Windows) is 32 bytes. Max value is 65500 (limitation imposed by Windows API).

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.DontFragment
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to prevent fragmentation of the ICMP packets. Currently CoreFX not supports this on Unix.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.Repeat
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to continue pinging until user presses Ctrl-C (or Int.MaxValue threshold reached).

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.Quiet
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to enable quiet output mode, reducing output to a single simple value only. By default, PingStatus, PingMtuStatus, or TraceStatus objects are emitted. With this switch, standard ping and -Traceroute returns only true / false, and -MtuSize returns an integer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.TimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the timeout value for an individual ping in seconds. If a response is not received in this time, no response is assumed. The default (from Windows) is 5 seconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.TargetName
member.summary: Gets or sets the destination hostname or IP address.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.MtuSize
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to detect Maximum Transmission Unit size. When selected, only a single ping result is returned, indicating the maximum buffer size the route to the destination can support without fragmenting the ICMP packets.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.Traceroute
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to perform a traceroute test.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand.TcpPort
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to perform a TCP connection test.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Lists processes currently running.

member.name: P:ProcessCommandHelpResources.GetProcessDetailedDescription
member.summary:
Looks up a localized string similar to
-Id id [int[]] [pipeline input allowed] Comma-separated list of process identifiers that specify the processes to get
-ProcessName name [string[]] [pipeline input allowed] Comma-separated list of process names that specify the processes to get
-Exclude name [ArrayList] Comma-separated list of process names to be excluded from the output.
--- The command enumerates processes from the local computer, and outputs System.Diagnostics.Process object(s). The command writes the process object to the output pipeline one at a time. The command takes parameters like ID(Process Identifier) or Process Name from the command line. The command returns the corresponding system.diagnostics.process for the supplied ID or ProcessName parameters.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Returns all running processes.
